Events this weekend and beyond

5 fun things this week

LCJ 8:22 a.m. EDT October 22, 2014

Important schedule.(Photo: Getty Images/iStockphoto )

CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The World's Largest Halloween Party. Louisville Zoo, 1100 Trevilian Way, Thursday-Sunday. Enter the zoo 5-8:30 p.m. The party provides not-so-scary fun for families and features costumed characters, storybook scenes throughout the zoo, trick-or-treating (for ages 11 and younger), Spooktacular Carousel ($2); The Halloween Express Train ($4); The Headless Horseman of Sleepy Hollow Tour ($2); Kaman's Handimals (starts at $10); Kaman's Face painting (starts at $8); Kaman's photo packages (start at $15) and Louisville Youth Board Face Painting and Sand Art ($1-$4). Presented by Meijer's. Admission, $9 advance ticket (online); $10 day of event. (502) 459-2181. www.louisvillezoo.org.

Jack O' Lantern Spectacular. Iroquois Park, behind Iroquois Amphitheater, dusk to 11 p.m. Thursday; dusk to midnight Friday and Saturday; dusk to 11 p.m. Sunday through Oct. 22. Local artists will carve more than 5,000 pumpkins, which will light a trail the length of five football fields. Proceeds benefit Louisville Metro Parks Foundation. Through Nov. 2. Tickets: Sunday-Thursday, $12, $10 seniors, $9 ages 3-12; Friday and Saturday, $15, $13 seniors, $12 for ages 3-12. www.jackolanternlouisville.com.

Oldham Arts on Quality Place Juried Art Show. Indoor Arena, YMCA, 20 Quality Place, Buckner, 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Saturday; 11 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday. Local and regional artists with jewelry, metal work, sculptures, paintings, photos and more. Proceeds to benefit the YMCA and Arts Association of Oldham County. (502) 222-9358.

BARS & CLUBS: 5 spots for live music

CONCERTS: Shows you don't want to miss

TAKE THE KIDS: 4 fun things for families

ON STAGE: 5 theater productions now playing

Super Hero 1K Walk/Run/Fly. Tyler Park, 1501 Castlewood Ave., Saturday. Registration at 4 p.m.; 1K at 5 p.m. Participants dress in their favorite Super Hero costume and run, walk or fly from Tyler Park to the Monkey Wrench Bar and Pub, 1025 Barret Ave. Also a costume contest, music, door prizes and food. Must be age 21 or older. Proceeds to benefit Boys & Girls Haven. Registration fee, $20. www.boyshaven.org.

Locust Grove 18th Century Market Fair. 561 Blankenbaker Lane, 10 a.m.-4:30 p.m. Saturday-Sunday. Features 18th century style entertainment, mock battles, concessions and replicas of 18th century military and household items for sale. $8, $4 children. (502) 897-9845. www.locustgrove.org.

And lots more fun stuff ...

Halloween

Danger Run. 7-11 p.m. Friday-Saturday. Starts at Lowe's at 501 Hurstbourne Parkway; 6651 Dixie Highway; or 1350 Veterans Parkway, Clarksville. Haunted house scavenger hunt, $10 free gas if you have four or more people in the car, free food from DQ Grill & Chill and vampire fangs. Through Nov. 1. $20. www.dangerrun.com.

Nightmare Forest Haunted Park. Otter Creek Outdoor Recreation Area (formerly Otter Creek Park), near Muldraugh and Fort Knox, along Ky. 1638, near U.S. 31W., Brandenburg, dusk to 2 a.m. Friday and Saturday. Features Nightmare Forest trail; a second haunted trail, The Trail of Terror; Nightmare Forest Drive-In and Hawthorne's Circus Bizarre. Known for bringing movies to life, this year features "Halloween," "Friday the 13th," "Texas Chainsaw Massacre," "Hellraiser," "The Conjuring" and "The Purge." General admission, $19 advance, $20 at the door; speed pass, $26 advance, $30 at the door. www.yournightmarebegins.com.

7th Street Haunt. 2900 7th Street Road, 8 p.m.-2 a.m. Friday and Saturday; 8-10:30 p.m. Sunday. Over 13,000 square feet of horrific terror and a casket ride. Through Nov. 2. $15 online; $18 at the door. www.7thstreethaunt.com.

Asylum Haunted Scream Park. 3101 Pond Station Road, 8 p.m.-2 a.m. Friday and Saturday. Four attractions, Darkness Falls on Asylum, Zombie City, Xterminate: Zalien Attack and Carnivale of Lost Souls. Recommended for ages 10 and older. Through Nov. 1. $28. www.asylumhaunts.com.

The Devil's Attic. 647 W. Hill St., 8 p.m.-12:30 a.m. Friday and Saturday; 8-11 p.m. Sunday. Haunted house. Children under 12 must be accompanied by an adult. Through Nov. 1. $18, $24 for speed pass. www.thedevilsattic.com.

The Haunted Hotel. 3000 S. Fourth St., 8 p.m.-midnight Thursday and Sunday; 8 p.m.-2 a.m. Friday and Saturday. Through Nov. 1. $20, $29 VIP fast pass. www.hauntedhotelky.com.

Grim Trails. 12009 Rehl Road, dusk to 12:30 a.m. Friday and Saturday. Not recommended for children under age 10. Through Nov. 1. $15, $10 for ages 10 and younger. www.grimtrails.com.

11th Annual Bardstown Bound: Boo Fest. Douglass Loop, Bardstown Road, Baxter Ave. and Douglass Loop, 2 p.m. Saturday. Haunted boutiques, bars, trick or treating, shopping, drinking, eating and entertainment. ValuMarket will host a costume contest and candy maze. www.bardstownbound.com.

Corn Island Scary Tales. Blackacre Conservancy, 3200 Tucker Station Road, 7 p.m. Saturday. Storytellers share spooky tales. $8, $15 family; members, $5, $10 family. (502) 266-9802

Boo Dell at Yew Dell. 6220 Old LaGrange Road, Crestwood, 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday. Trick-or-treating, hayrides, scavenger hunt and a magic show at 2 p.m. $5 per carload. (502) 241-4788. www.yewdellgardens.org.

80th Annual Halloween Parade. Downtown Corydon, 6 p.m. Saturday. The parade proceeds north on Capitol Ave.

Halloween Mask Making Workshop. Museum of the American Printing House for the Blind, 1839 Frankfort Ave., 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m. Saturday. Free, registration required. (502) 899-2213.

Events

Oldham Arts on Quality Place Juried Art Show Preview Party. Indoor Arena, YMCA, 20 Quality Place, Buckner, 6-9:30 p.m. Friday. Artists will open their booths for a preview sale, music by Joe Debow, appetizers, dinner and live and silent auctions. The Oldham Award of Excellence will be presented to Bill Samuels. $85, $75 for YMCA and AAOC members. ymcalouisville.org/oldham-county or (502) 222-9358.

Walden Theatre Fall Benefit. ReSurfaced, 615-621 W. Main St., 6-8:30 p.m. Friday. Performance of "Revenge of Lenore," food trucks, beer garden, raffles, silent auction, costume contest, face painting, bake sale and music by Billy Goat Strut Revue. waldentheatre.org.

Nearly New Shop Fall Fashion Encore. Mid-City Mall, lower level, 1250 Bardstown Road, 10 a.m. -6 p.m. Saturday; 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday. Shop new and nearly new designer clothing for men, women and children, shoes/boots, accessories and household items at discount prices. Proceeds benefit community based programs that help women, children and families in the community. shopnearlynew.org.

National Young Bird Show. Pavilion, Kentucky Exposition Center, 937 Phillips Lane, 9 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday. More than 6,000 birds of show quality on display and 650 exhibitors. Free. Parking $8, $20 bus. (502) 367-5000.

9th Annual Spirit Ball Masquerade & Dance: "Celebrating the Spirits of the Belle." Conrad-Caldwell House Museum, 1402 St. James Court, 7 p.m. Saturday. Cocktails, food, music, silent and live auctions and costume contest. $150. The After Party, after the ball, 9:30 p.m.-12:30 a.m. Entertainment by Sheryl Rouse Crawford, cocktails and light hors d'oeuvres. $50. Proceeds benefit Conrad-Caldwell House Museum. (502) 636-5023.

Skid Markz Car Club Benefit. Big O Tires, 3751 Pamela Rae Drive, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Sunday. Registration 10 a.m.-1 p.m. Benefit for Abigail Rose, who was diagnosed with leukemia. Silent auction, food, awards and costume contest for children. Bring a bag of candy for trick-or-treaters. $10 entry fee. (502) 750-1220.

Making Strides Against Breast Cancer 5K. Waterfront Park, Sunday. Registration 10 a.m.; walk 1 p.m. Participants collect donations. main.acsevents.org/site/TR?pg=entry&fr_id=62679; (502) 560-6043.

Literary

Kentucky Shakespeare's Candlelight Reading of "Macbeth." ReSurfaced, 615-621 W. Main St., 8 p.m. Saturday. Food trucks, beer, wine, spirits and Heine Brothers coffee. Free.

Tastings

Wine & Whiskey Night: Cabernets for a Cure. Westport Whiskey & Wine, 1115 Herr Lane, 6-8 p.m. Thursday. Cabernets from California. A portion of the sales will be donated to The V Foundation. Wines to be tasted include: Simi, Clos Du Bois, Estancia, Wild Horse and Dreaming Tree. Wines $3 by-the-glass and $2 whiskeys.

Italian Wine Blowout Tasting with Mollie Lewis of Indigenous Selections. Westport Whiskey & Wine, 1115 Herr Lane, 7 p.m. Friday. This tasting will pair some robust reds, from Barolo, Barbaresco and Tuscany with some great food. $30, $25 for Tasting Club Members. Reservations, (502) 708-1313.

Big Reds from Tramonte & Sons. Westport Whiskey & Wine, 1115 Herr Lane, 7 p.m. Tuesday. Wines from California's Napa and Sonoma counties. $25, $20 for Tasting Club Members. (502) 708-1313.

Film

Planetarium shows. Gheens Science Hall & Rauch Planetarium, 108 W. Brandeis Ave. $8, $6 for ages 12 and younger, seniors and University of Louisville students. (502) 852-6664.

Friday: "Dynamic Earth," 8 p.m.; "Laser Fright Light," 9 p.m.; "Black Holes: The Other Side of Infinity," 10 p.m.; "Laser Pink Floyd: Dark Side of the Moon," 11 p.m.

Saturday:

"Perfect Little Planet," 1 p.m.; "Laser Fright Light," 2 p.m.; "Oasis in Space," 3 p.m.

Cruise

Belle of Louisville Dinner/Sightseeing Cruise. River Road, 7-9 p.m. Thursday and Friday. $43, $42 seniors, $27 children. Sightseeing only, $21, $20 seniors, $12 children. (502) 574-2992.

Belle of Louisville Lunch/Sightseeing Cruise. River Road, noon-2 p.m. Friday and Saturday. $35, $34 seniors, $25 children. Sightseeing only, $21, $20 seniors, $12 children. (502) 574-2992.

Spirit of Jefferson Harbor Cruise. River Road, 3-4 p.m. Saturday. $15, $9 children. (502) 574-2992.

Spirit of Jefferson Dinner/Sightseeing Cruise. River Road, 7-9 p.m. Saturday and Tuesday. $43, $42 seniors, $27 children. Sightseeing only, $21, $20 seniors, $12 children. (502) 574-2992.

Spirit of Jefferson Lunch/Sightseeing Cruise. Fourth and River Road, noon-2 p.m. July 16. $35, $34 seniors, $25 children. Sightseeing only, $21, $20 seniors, $12 children. (502) 574-2992.

Hike/Walks

M

int Julep

Tours: The Moonshine & Madness.

Leaving from Haymarket Whiskey Bar, 331 E Market St., 7:30 p.m. Thursday. Combines a bus and walking tour with stops on the Urban Bourbon Trail with spooky Louisville sites including the Jack-O-Lantern Spectacular. $57. Reservations: Chasta Feller, chasta@mintjuleptours.com; (502) 583-1433.

LouisvilleGhost Walks. The Brown Hotel, 335 W. Broadway, 7:30 p.m. Friday; 7 p.m. Saturday. A 90-minute walk in downtown Louisville. Mention reading this listing and receive $2 off walk. Reservation suggested. $15. (502) 689-5117.

Dances

Nuts N Honeys Dance Club. Dance Louisville, 8023 Catherine Lane, 7-11 p.m. Friday. Beginner and intermediate line dancing and couples dancing. $5. (502) 643-2786 or bigalofamerica@aol.com.

Singles Dance. Moose Lodge, 4615 Fegenbush Lane, 7:30-11 p.m. Sunday. Music by Kenny Sauter's Masters of Music DJ Service. Door prizes. $6, $2 off before 8 p.m. (502) 736-7600.

Exhibits

21c Museum Hotel. 700 W. Main St. "Transporting Transformation: Cuba, In and Out," by Jose Toirac, Sandra Ramos and others; "Chito Yoshida: Love for Sale," by Chito Yoshida; "A Thirsty Switch Still Quivers For Me," by Gina Phillips. "Burnouts," by Julia Christensen. All end April 2015. (502) 217-6300.

849 Gallery. Kentucky School of Art, 849 S. Third St. "Armatures of Audubon: Contemporary Construction and Ecologies." Ends Friday.

Actors Theatre Gallery. 316 W. Main St. "The Bard and The Binghams: Shakespeare at Actors Theatre." Ends Oct. 31.

The Art Council Southern Indiana. Pat Harrison Gallery, 820 E. Market St., New Albany. "Harlan Hubbard: Plain Living, High Thinking - Part 1. "Personal Flotation Device: An Interactive Installation," by Susan Harrsion. Both end Nov. 1.

Asia Institute Crane House. 1244 S. Third St. Opening Friday, "Poking the Lillies Pad," ceramic works by nationally recognized, emerging Asian American artists. Ends March 15.

B. Deemer Gallery. 2650 Frankfort Ave. "Alloquerer," paintings by Carolyn Young Hisel. Ends Nov. 12.

Bellarmine University McGrath Gallery. 2001 Newburg Road. "Train," by Caren Cunningham. Ends Nov. 1.

Carnegie Center for Art & History. 201 E. Spring St., New Albany. Opening Friday, "Earth-Tones: Art Quilts," by Penny Sisto. Reception Friday, 6-8 p.m. Ends Jan. 10.

Conrad-Caldwell House Museum. 1402 St. James Court. "Louisville's River." Ends May 31, 2015.

Craft(s) Gallery. 572 S. Fourth St. "Have You Any Wool?" by Catherine Bryant and Vallorie Henderson. Ends Oct. 31.

Flame Run Gallery. 815 W. Market St. Works by Steven Ciezki. Ends Nov. 22.

Frazier History Museum. 829 W. Main St. "Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous: Art, Fashion & Luxury During the Gilded Age." Ends Feb. 1.

Galerie Hertz. 1253 S. Preston. "Sycamore Shores/Modern Paintings & Drawings From the River," by Ray Kleinhelter. Ends Nov. 8.

Garner Narrative Contemporary Fine Art. 642 E. Market St. "Deconstructing Melancholy," by Aleksandra Stone. Ends Nov. 28.

The Green Building. 732 E. Market St. "Incommunicado," a three-dimensional exhibit by Amy Chase, Patrick Donley and Brad White. Ends Nov. 28.

Horseshoe Gallery. Horseshoe Casino, 11999 Casino Center Drive, Elizabeth, Ind. "Delectable." Ends Dec. 31.

Huff Gallery. Spalding University, 853 Library Lane. "Contemporary Prints From the Calliope Arts Print Collection." Ends Friday.

Indiana University Southeast Barr Gallery. 4201 Grant Line Road. "The Life of Brian: A 36 Year View," by Brian H. Jones. Ends Nov. 21.

Jane Morgan Gallery. 4838 Brownsboro Center. "Olmsted Parks Paintings II" and "Life Drawings of Charcoal, Pastel, Oil and Acrylic." Both end Oct. 31.

Jeffersontown Historical Museum. 10635 Watterson Trail. Historic photos and artifacts. Ends Dec. 19.

Kentucky Derby Museum. 704 Central Ave. "Horse Play," highlighting the playful side of the Kentucky Derby and featuring historical equine toys, digital interactives and music created for the museum. Ends Dec. 31. (502) 637-1111.

Kentucky Museum of Art & Craft. 715 W. Main St. "Ritual & Residue: The Art of Drink." Ends Nov. 9. (502) 589-0102.

Kentucky Science Center. 727 W. Main St. "The World We Create." Permanent exhibit that explores science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through collaborative and open-ended challenges.

Kentucky Watercolor Society Gallery. 4836 Brownsboro Center. Kentucky Watercolor Society Plein Air Exhibit. Ends Oct. 30.

Kore Gallery. Mellwood Art Center, 1860 Mellwood Ave. "Expressions in Imagination," by Mary Jane Allen. Ends Nov. 2.

Leslie H. Spetz Custom Picture Framing. 2400 Lime Kiln Lane, Suite C. Works by Jaime Corum, Lynn Dunbar, Robert Halliday and David Schuster. Ends Oct. 31. (502) 426-8880.

Local Speed. 822 E. Market St. "Working Hands: A Modern Generation Explores the Ancient Craft of Textiles," textiles created by the children of the Cabbage Patch Settlement House. "Discovering the Earth: African Pottery From the Speed's Collection." Both end Saturday. info@speedmuseum.org.

Louisville Free Public Library. 301 York St. "Black Freedom, White Allies and Red Scare: Louisville, 1954." Ends Nov. 29.

Metro Hall. 527 W. Jefferson St. "Infinite Perspectives," by Ann Stewart Anderson, Ashley Brossart and Dhamin Jassim. Ends Jan. 16.

Paul Paletti Gallery. 713 E. Market St. "Small Worlds," photographs by Margaret Oechsli. Ends Dec. 29.

Peyton Samuel Head Family Museum. Oldham County History Center, 106 N. Second St., La Grange. "I Pledge Allegiance: Honoring Our World War II Veterans." Ends March 22, 2015.

Portland Museum. 2308 Portland Ave. Works by Julius Friedman. Ends Dec. 23.

Pyro Gallery. 909 E. Market St. "Collected Materials + Familiar Things," by Kim Huber. Ends Nov. 15.

Revelry Boutique Gallery. 742 E. Market. "Weird Like Me," by Dustin Dirt. Ends Nov. 6.

Roberta Marx Gallery. Thomas Jefferson Unitarian Church, 4936 Brownsboro Road. "Hand-Made Book Show." Ends Oct. 31.

Swanson Contemporary. 638 E. Market St. "19+1 A Collaboration," by Joel Feldman, students of Common Good and Lexington Art League. Ends Nov. 15.

University of Louisville Hite Art Institute. Belknap Campus. "Deep Ecology," by Ying Kit Chan. Ends Nov. 1.

Wayside Expressions Gallery. Wayside Christian Mission, 120 W. Broadway. "Three Women, One Show," painting and photography exhibit. Ends Nov. 4.

Zephyr Gallery. 610 E. Market St. "Project 4...sweet Home." Ends Saturday.

Other attractions

Lazer Blaze. 4121 Shelbyville Road, Friday, 4 p.m.-midnight; Saturday, 10 a.m.-midnight; Sunday, noon-9 p.m.; Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, 4-9 p.m. Laser tag, laser tag museum, arcade, cafe. $7 per game, $12 for two games. (502) 895-2985.

Robben's Roost. 5906 Six Mile Lane, Friday, 7-11 p.m.; Saturday, 1-4 and 7:30-10:30 p.m.; Sunday, 1-4 p.m.; Tuesday and Thursday, 11 a.m.-1 p.m. Roller skating. Fridays, $6; Saturday afternoons, $4, evenings, $5; Sundays, $4; Tuesdays and Thursdays, $3. (502) 491-8170.

Skate World. 6310 Preston Highway, 7-11 p.m. Fridays; 1-4 and 7-11 p.m. Saturdays; 1-4 p.m. Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays. Roller skating. Friday and Saturday evenings, $5; Saturday and Sunday afternoons, $4; Tuesdays and Thursdays, $3. (502) 969-6000.

Wheel Fun Rentals. Waterfront Park. 10 a.m.-7 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. Bike rentals: cruisers, tandems, choppers, quad sports, deuce coupes, four-wheel surrey bikes. Group rates available. www.wheelfunrentals.com.

Open Range Sports. 6401 Cross Keys Blvd., Crestwood, 4-8 p.m. Friday; 11 a.m.-8 p.m. Saturday; noon-5 p.m. Sunday. Indoor paintball/reball and a gun range. (502) 243-8282; www.openrangesports.com.
